This in turn was ed after a tribe of Indians who inhabited its lower banks. Created by the 1844-1845 Session of the State Legislature, Act passed Feb, 8, 1845, which took effect May 1, 1845, mbraced parts of Buckingham, Prince Edward, Charlotte Campbell Counties, the general boundaries being set forth he Act, and subsequently was surveyed in the months of r June and July of that year by John Patteson, S. B. Co., ander Austin, Sur. Campbell Co., and Z. E. Cheatham, 1 had been appointed Surveyor of Appomattox County. It junded on the northwest by James River, and situated in the h central part of Virginia, and covers an area of 217,792 s, or approximately 340 square miles. The Act provided that the Governor should commission as ices of the Peace, for the County of Appomattox, the Jus- L commissioned and residing in those sections of the  counties that would be in Appomattox County, after the imencement of said Act. f The Court for the County was composed of the Justices resaid, who were to meet on Thursday after the first Mon in each month, after the same was organized, at the place wn as Clover Hill, the residence of Capt. Smiths resignation was motivated by reasons of health and came with four years remaining in his current term of office. The resignation was submitted to Circuit Court Judge George F. Abbitt. Mr. Smith was bom In Fred erick County, Maryland, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. M. C. Smith. The family moved to Ap pomattox in 1907. He began his distinguished service in the Clerks office Feb. 8, 1908, as a Deputy Clerk under toe late John Rolfe Horsley. He became Clerk in 1919 and was elected to that Office in the fall of that year, and was re-elected, without op position in the county elections Of 1927, 1935, 1943, 1951 and 1959. This is thought to be a record for the State and indicative of the high respect and esteem In which he is held and reflects tribute to the efficiency and high quality of public service render ed. Since its establishment in 18- 45, Appomattox County has had six County Clerks John T. Bo- cock, Henry F. Bocock, Geo. T. Peers, George W. Abbitt, John Rolfe Horsley and Mr. Smith. In addition to his career aa Clerk, Mr. Smith has been most active in community, county and Church affairs. He was one at the drigttler of toe Appomat tox Light it Power Company In 1922. He wrote tf -Charter for the Town of .Appomattox when it was incorporated in 1925. He has served as Vice-President and Chairman of the Board of The Bank of Appomattox. He has served as Chairman of the Official Board of Memorial Methodist Church for 14 years served as Church Treasuer for 30 years. Superintendent of the Church School for 42 years and as a merriber of Monroe Lodge 301 AF  AM, Woodmen of the World and Appomattox L i o n s Club. In October of 1915, he was married to Miss Lucye Cabell Foster, who is an outstanding leader in local civic and church affairs. On toe occasion of the Cenn tennial of the forming of Appo mattox County in 1945, Mr. Smith wrote a splendid history of toe! county, which was widely dis tributed in booklet form. Despite the press of his many duties, he has found time for his favorite hobby, that of gardening, and his flower garden has been a show- place of the community. In World War II he served on the Appomattox Selective Service Board and through the years, Whenever the Community and! county needed the services of this modest and capable leader. document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. Bocock, James Watkins, D. Mott Robertson, W. C. Franklin, H. D. Flood, J. W. Harwood, Ster ling C. Stratton, Willis H. Ligon, J. R. Horsley, J. C. Jones, A. B. Thornhill, T. J. Stratton, J. W. This was the nathe given to an old colonial town situated on the north side of Appoiiattox River, just be low the sire of the Cut Bauk bridge that used to span the river at that place. The town was at the head of what was then flat-bottom boat navi gatiou on Appomattox River, which was made so by the aid of sluice and dam improvement. Under the old British regulation the land was condemned, streets laid off, and the town Incorporated, bin it seems never to have been built up for a warehouse and tavern are tin only buildings of which we have any account. Perhaps the .GlUteU8, like those of old Jamestown, thought tin laud would be more valuable put in tobacco, aud who knows but they were right. Anyhow it was never built up, On the west side of the fown is the Cut Bank road, leading from Hopeville, Buckingham county, to Hurtsville and Hixburg, Appomat ,tox on the north, the elegant old mansion of - William R. Gilliam grandson of old Isham Gilliam, the celebrated fox hunter, who threw off his coat once iu an exciting chase and, finding it a month afterward swore it belonged to a runaway negro, for putting it to Ins nose he said it smelt like one, Th Madame could hardly convince him of his mistake. Here Mr. William R. Gilliam entertains his guests and friends in the most hospitable man ner, Qn the east is Woods Moun tain, which, jjsjpg jp all its majestic grandeur, throws itg shadow over hill aud dale. The mountain road crosses this m o u n ta in , running from Jones Mill road to the Cut Bank road through Pluuterstown, planned by old Mr. John Bocock, comniis sio.ier. Qn this road is the celebrated Rock Spring, gushiug from a rocky bed underneath an immense shelv ing rock, aud descending three or four feet to the reservoir below. It is a place of great resort for level lasses and then beaux, from which they ascend to the grand scenery above. Some eighteeu mouths ago a happy pair lost their way, passed ard repassed the spring without see ing it, although the lady declared she had bee there often before, and I had to pilot them to the place, The lady seemed veiy disconsolate and I had to console her by saying that such thiugs were of common occurrence, as I once myself, under almost similar circumstances, left a broad country road that I had often traveled and turned up in a cow-pen.

Bocock. amid an assembly of representaive Virginian Confederates Dr. Smith, chaplain of the Museum being master of ceremonies, in troduemg the speakers. Judge George L. Christian made an instructive and eloquent address, iu which he reviewed the seventy seven years of Speaker Bococks life, In his introduction he said in trying to honor the good and true we honor ourselves, and we are doing that this morning. He commenced from his birth in Buckingham county, and took his audience through the varied scenes of his life, his election to Con gress iu 1847 for seven consecutive terms, duriug which several branches of the Navy were reformed. At th conclusion, Mastor Thomas Bocock Price namesake and oldest grand child, unveiled the portrait. Hon. John Goode accepted the portrait on behalf of the ladies of the Confederate Museum, in au eloquent and patriotic speech, which was frequently interrupted by bursts of applause. document.text: Spanish Oaks Item s. Spanish Oaks, Va., May, 4th, 1896. We have had fine rains and feel much encouraged at the improved condition of the crops in general is to be earnestly hoped that a eat part of the army of chinch- bugs shared the fate of Pharaohs army. Many of the neighbors are busy day receiving shipments of guano Concord Depot. Tobacco plants are pushing the farmers in their preparations for filling. We greatly appreciate the kind ness done us by Mr. Jos. Button, when in Washington, in securing desirable changes in onr mail route, which enables us to get our mails a day earlier. Mr. T. M. Lewis has qualified as Post Master to succeed Miss Alice Stratton who recently re signed, and be will soon assume charge of the office. At a recent meeting of the Stone wall Improvement Society one of the speakers, in describing a man who could resist feminine charms, com pared him to a bristled swine walk ing on his hind legs and was loudly applauded by the young ladies pres ent, and their escorts also. That speaker might be said to be strictly iu it. Mrs. S. M. Bocock who has been 4B paying a short visit to this neigh borhood, will leave go day for her nome at Hampden Sidney. She is  ust returning from Arkansas where she has been spending some months with her daughter, Rev. Mrs. Wil lis. Mr. E. L. Thornhill returned to Lynchburg last week from paying a visit of several days to his home near heie. We are sorry to note the extreme illness of Mrs, John Scruggs. Her recovery is almost despaired of by Dr. Rice. She has been sick for some months. C o a l in g .

document.text: Mrs. Martha A. Gills, a for mer resident of Appomattox, died at the home of her daugh ter, Mrs. T. L. Payne, in Crewe, April 11. Mrs. Gills was 93 years of age. She was a daugh ter of the late Captain Wilson Hix, of Appomattox, a leader in the community which play ed so dramatic a part in the War Between the States. Her mother was a sister of Hon. Thomas S. Bocock, of Appo mattox, who was the speaker of the House during the brief re gime of the Confederacy. Mrs. Gills remembered vivid ly the circumstances of the sur render of General Lee at Appo mattox. The surrender took place on a farm owned by her rather, and the terms of sur render were drawn and signed in a building formerly owned by her father, who sold it to Major McLean during the war. General Grant took possession of her fathers home for eight days while the Confederate sol diers were being paroled. When the Union soldiers were beginning to evacuate the village, an officer approached the young daughter of the house and informed her that he had hidden away a barrel of flour and a chicken, so that when they were gone her fami ly might not suffer for provi sions. The gloom of war was bright ened for Mrs. Gills by the ro mantic attachment she felt for her first cousin, Daniel Gills, a young cavalrymen in Fitzhughjj Lees brigade, which after the war culminated in marriage. On Deo. 51st., on the Lynchburg and Durham railroad, about six miles from Lynqhburg, a terrible crime was committed. Some- three weeks prior to the tragedy, the young and attractive daughter of Mr. J. H. White, of Lynchburg, was married to Pleasant Hendricks, of Campbell co.unty. They made their home near Bocock Station shortly afterward, and livedhappily together. On the night of Dep. 21st. between 9 and 10 oclook, Mrs. Hendricks was sitting in her room reading The Chil dren of the Abbeyand Mr.Hendrioks was asleep. There was bnt little flip on the hearth. The door was bolted with an ordinary lock bolt. All at once it was broken down and four masked men rushed into the room. One of them held an axe in bis hand, and rushing to the bed struck Hendricks on the head with the sharp edge. Mrs. Hendricks, over come by the right fainted, and when she became conscious was lying on a hastily improvised- pallet out in the yard, where she supposed she had been taken by the murderers. Thie house was enveloped iiyflames. Many of the neighbors were attracted by the light, but arrived too late to ex tinguish the Are or to rescue the body. er trunk had also been refnpved and was placed so near the burning building that it caught on fire and was entirely consumed. While the crowd stood about the burning house it was whispered around that four negroes from Jaok- son Town, a small suburb of Lynofar burg, bad been seen hunting in the neighborhood. Suspicion being arous ed, parties were immediately dis- latohed to arrest them. A ndthis was accomplished before morningi hree of the negroes were arrested by officers, and the fourth one sur rendered himself. In the meantime, when the flames died down, a search wB instituted tot the murdered man, and after a long hunt they found what was left of the body. The heart, lungs and a few fragments of bones were all that remained of what a few hours before bad been a prosperous,happy human beidg. Mr. Hendricks was an industrious and well-to-do farmer of about forty-five years of age, ahd was not known to have bad an enemy. On the day before, however, be had brought home 200, He had given bis wife 15 and placing the remain der in an oil cloth sack had con cealed it in the bed.. It is thought, that, as Mr. Hendricks had been hauling posts to Jackson Town while he had this money in his pos session, the negroes must have dis covered the fact and planned the robbery. On Dec. 23rd an inquisition was held at the scene of the crime, anc. was adjoqrned to the 27th to the Law Building at Lynchburg. Mr. W. M. Murrell, assisted by Mr. Thos. Whitehead, Jr., conducted the exam ination for tbe commonwealth, while the prisoners were represented by Maj. T. J. Kirkpatrick, Judge H. M. Ford and Mr. James W. Wright. The only witness called was Mrs. Hendricks. She identified the fonr negroes as the persons who entered her house, bnt her testimony die i not 6onvince the coroners jury for they were divided in their opinions as to the guilt of the men arrested who were Commodore Johnson, Rob ert Smith, William Coghill and William Fields. The coroner, Mr. John W. Gills, and three of the jnrors declared the deed to have been perpetrated by tbe prisoners, while the remaining three decided that the fatal blow had been struck by parties unknown. The  murder continues to be the all-absorbing topic of conversation among the county people. Many now believe that the four negroes are the guilty parties, while many others do not think that the right men have been captured and, from the latest reports, we learn that considerable indignation is expressed at the unnecessary detention of the prisoners. ________________ Toga Notes.
